title: Mechanisms behind the exceptional longevity of freshwater mussels
impactText: Our results will be used by other academics interested in the processe of ageing and the mechanisms controlling negligible senescance and exceptional longevity Environment
findingsText: We investigated a range of freshwater mussel species to see if their extreme longevity e.g. the pearl mussel mean life span (MLP = 190 years) was associated with an enhanced resistance to oxidative stress. Our data perhaps surprisingly did not support the premise that extreme longevity is assocaited with enhanced resistance to oxidative stress. In fact pearl mussels were least resistant to oxidative stress compared to shorter-lived freshwater bivalve species. These finding will be of interest to gerontologists who are concerned with investigating the reasons for the extreme longevity in invertebrates compared with short-lived terrestrial mammals.
